title: I have done cocaine only 3 times, but now I have a strong urge to do it again. Does this mean I'm addicted? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are several different conditions that we consider addictions, and each family of “addictive” drugs interacts with them differently. Think about each of these and decide how they apply to you. Rebound. if you enjoy the way you feel on cocaine, this means that you don’t enjoy the way you feel without it. Rebound is where you start feeling like you just can’t live life the way you want to without a drug. If you start thinking “I’m going to need this drug to make it through this”, then you have this form of addiction. Conditioning: Opioids will rewire the brain so that, when you consider what would make you happy, the opioid will feel, emotionally, like a far better idea than it really is. Alcohol does this, too. This is primarily an issue with alcohol and heroin, but can be found in dopamine agonists like cocaine, too. Withdrawal. You’ve probably had a hangover. Some of us crawl under the covers and wait for the hangover to go away. Others try hair of the dog. This probably isn’t your problem, but it’s a strong contributor for nicotine and methamphetamine. The Rational Belief That The Drug Is Useful. This is actually the opposite of an addiction, but it needs to be teased away from the other factors in order to recognize which components of your desire to do it again are actually the addiction taking hold. The biggest issue with the world’s dialog regarding drugs is the idea that there are no rational reasons to be taking drugs. There’s no rational reason to want to be happy, either, when you think about it. This mentality makes it difficult if not impossible to recognize an addiction because, for drugs without major corporate sponsorship, any desire to use them can be called an addiction.

Yes, your body is what we addicts call “feening” for the drug.
